items.title: data not mapping to x in geom_boxplot
items.body:
The example data can be downloaded [here](https://github.com/chenyulue/resource-data/blob/master/Oxboy.csv). This data comes from `nlme` package in R, which records the height (`height`) and centered ages (`age`) of 26 boys (`Subject`), measured on nine occasion (`Occasion`). 

Now I want to plot a boxplot with `Occasion` mapping to `x` and `height` to `y` to see the height distribution per `Occasion`. The code is as follows:

```python
import pandas as pd
from plotnine import *
oxboys = pd.read_csv('Oxboy.csv')
ggplot(oxboys, aes('Occasion', 'height')) + geom_boxplot()
```

The figure obtained is [not correct](https://github.com/chenyulue/resource-data/blob/master/Figure_1.png), which doesn't map the `Occasion` to `x`.

However, this can be solved with the following snippet:
```python
ggplot(oxboys, aes('Occasion', 'height', group='Occasion')) + geom_boxplot()
```
[The correct figure](https://github.com/chenyulue/resource-data/blob/master/Figure_2.png)

But I think this should be a bug, because according to the Grammar of Graphics, `ggplot(oxboys, aes('Occasion', 'height')) + geom_boxplot()` should have given the correct figure. In fact, in `ggplot2` of R-lang the same snippet works right.

items.title: Group facet_grid labels
items.body:
Is there a way to group labels when using plotnine's `facet_grid` function? 

For example, take the following DataFrame (I made the example up such that you can reproduce my problem. In real my DataFrame is much bigger but the structure is almost identical):

    df_test = pd.DataFrame(data= {'rate_1': [0.0,0.1,0.2,0.3,0.0,0.1,0.2,0.3,0.3,0.2,0.1,0.0],
                                  'rate_2': [0.0,0.1,0.2,0.3,0.0,0.1,0.2,0.3,0.3,0.2,0.1,0.0],
                                  'rate_3':[0.0,0.1,0.2,0.3,0.0,0.1,0.2,0.3,0.3,0.2,0.1,0.0],
                                  'rate_4': [0.0,0.1,0.2,0.3,0.1,0.2,0.3,0.0,0.2,0.3,0.0,0.1],
                                  'samples': [50000, 100000, 50000, 100000,50000, 100000, 50000, 100000,50000, 100000, 50000, 100000],
                                  'model': ['model 1', 'model 2', 'model 3', 'model 4','model 1', 'model 2', 'model 3', 'model 4','model 1', 'model 2', 'model 3', 'model 4'],
                                  'metric': [0.5,0.4,0.3,0.2,0.5,0.4,0.3,0.2,1,0.3,0.4,0.3]})


I created the following function to plot the absolute metric depending on the rates, sample size and model:

    # Plotting
    my_plot = ggplot(data=df_test, mapping=aes('rate_1', 'rate_2', fill='metric'))
    my_plot += geom_tile()
    my_plot += theme(axis_text_x=element_text(rotation=90), figure_size=(16, 8), strip_background_x=element_text(width=1.))
    my_plot += scale_x_continuous(breaks=[.0, .1, .2, .3, .4, .5])
    my_plot += scale_y_continuous(breaks=[.0, .1, .2, .3, .4, .5])
    my_plot += facet_grid('rate_3 + samples  ~ model + rate_4', labeller=label_value)
    my_plot += scale_fill_gradient2(midpoint=0, low='blue', mid="white", high="red")
    my_plot

The resulting plot looks like:

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

Is there a way to group model names (model 1, model 2, model 3, model 4) and rate_4 when labeling the facet_grid? I'm looking for a result such that the 'columns' are named like the following (I used Excel for the illustration):

[![enter image description here][2]][2]

I also posted my question on [stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63338071/plotnine-group-facet-grid-labels)

Thanks!


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/o3zIL.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/rbQVp.png

items.title: Plot with different geoms and legend
items.body:
Hello,

how can I combine multiple geoms and get a legend?
The first image is using separate data in a pandas data frame, see the code below to produce such an output.
![separate_columns](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14841658/89157443-d3834080-d56c-11ea-9c93-85fa6e05799d.png)
The second image uses tidy data, as far as I understood it. This produces the desired legend.
![tidy_data](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14841658/89157448-d54d0400-d56c-11ea-858a-beea3cee8482.png)
My goal is to get the first image but with legend. One data set as a black geom_line() and the other red geom_point() with tidy data, as this seems to be how it is done.
```
import pandas as pd
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import plotnine as pn

# define your x_values, measurements, data here

df = pd.DataFrame(data={
    'x': x_values,
    'y_measurement': measurements,
    'y_data': data
    })
df_melt = df.melt(id_vars=['x'], value_vars=['y_data', 'y_measurement'], var_name='data_type', value_name='data_and_measurement')
pn_handle = pn.ggplot(df) \
            + pn.aes(x='x') \
            + pn.geom_line(pn.aes(y='y_data'), color='black', alpha=1.0) \
            + pn.geom_point(pn.aes(y='y_measurement'), color='red', alpha=0.5) \
            + pn.labs(title='Title', x='Samples [n]', y='Value') \
            + pn.theme_light()
pn_handle.draw()
plt.show()

pn_handle = pn.ggplot(df_melt) \
            + pn.aes(x='x', y='data_and_measurement') \
            + pn.geom_line(pn.aes(color='data_type'), alpha=1.0) \
            + pn.geom_point(pn.aes(color='data_type'), alpha=0.5) \
            + pn.labs(title='Title', x='Samples [n]', y='Value') \
            + pn.theme_light()
pn_handle.draw()
plt.show()
```

items.title: bw parameter in stat_density
items.body:
First of all, thanks for providing this awesome package!

However, there is an issue w.r.t. to setting the bandwidth parameter. When setting the bw parameter in `stat_density` it is not passed through. Instead, the default value 'normal_reference' is used. Here is my small example:

`(ggplot(stats_plot_all, aes(x='values', color='task', fill='task'))
            + geom_density(alpha=0.1)
            + stat_density(bw=1.5)
            + facet_wrap('~metrics', nrow=6, ncol=3, scales='free'))`

Thanks for your time!

items.title: geom_point(): unfilled with outline
items.body:
Is it possible to have geom_point() with no fill, but just outline? 

I looked up plotnine API documentation, and did lots of Google search, but was not able to find how to do so...

In Matplotlib, you can specify `facecolors='none', edgecolors='black'` to have unfilled point with black outline

Looking at the `geom_point()` source, 

```
@staticmethod
    def draw_unit(data, panel_params, coord, ax, **params):
        # Our size is in 'points' while scatter wants
        # 'points^2'. The stroke is outside. And pi
        # gives a large enough scaling factor
        # All other sizes for which the MPL units should
        # be in points must scaled using sqrt(pi)
        size = ((data['size']+data['stroke'])**2)*np.pi
        stroke = data['stroke'] * SIZE_FACTOR
        color = to_rgba(data['color'], data['alpha'])

        # It is common to forget that scatter points are
        # filled and slip-up by manually assigning to the
        # color instead of the fill. We forgive.
        if all(c is None for c in data['fill']):
            fill = color
        else:
            fill = to_rgba(data['fill'], data['alpha'])

        ax.scatter(x=data['x'],
                   y=data['y'],
                   s=size,
                   facecolor=fill,
                   edgecolor=color,
                   linewidth=stroke,
                   marker=data.loc[0, 'shape'],
                   zorder=params['zorder'])
```
it seems it is not possible to have `facecolor=None`, and `edgecolor=black` as it automatically replaces `fill` value with `color` if `fill=None`.

I would appreciate any suggestions and/or help!

items.title: Documentation: link to stat_bin vs. python bin()
items.body:
Greetings,

I was just looking to refresh myself on the keywords to `geom_historgram`, reading [this page](https://plotnine.readthedocs.io/en/stable/generated/plotnine.geoms.geom_histogram.html). I realized that to find args like `bins` and `binwidth`, I need to look at the stat documentation, not `geom_histogram`:

> stat: str or stat, optional (default: [bin](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#bin))

Maybe just my opinion, but I'd guess most people don't want to go from plotnine docs to the general formula for bin(), they want to know how to use binning within the context of plotnine. But the only other relevant link is to [stat](https://plotnine.readthedocs.io/en/stable/glossary.html#term-stat), which looks like a class hierarchy page, not one listing stats/explaining how to use them.

Finding what I actually want required: API -> [stats](https://plotnine.readthedocs.io/en/stable/api.html#stats) -> [stat_bin](https://plotnine.readthedocs.io/en/stable/generated/plotnine.stats.stat_bin.html#plotnine.stats.stat_bin)

My opinion: if I'm looking at a page on usage, it makes the most sense to link to other relevant _usage_ pages (which is why I came to the docs), not something like object hierarchies or root function docs.

If you agree, I'd be glad to make PRs as I see things like this.

items.title: scale_x_discrete using limits breaks tick marks
items.body:
This issue is not explained by #342.

## Problem
This assigned tick marks in this plot seem incorrect:
```python
import plotnine as pn
import pandas as pd
pn.ggplot(pn.aes('a'), pd.DataFrame({'a':[2,2,3]})) + pn.geom_bar() \
    + pn.scale_x_discrete(limits=list(range(4)))
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4857068/80003010-b1374c80-84c0-11ea-8513-209a556f43fd.png)

However, using other limits does work correctly:
```python
pn.ggplot(pn.aes('a'), pd.DataFrame({'a':[2,2,3]})) + pn.geom_bar() \
    + pn.scale_x_discrete(limits=list(range(1, 5)))
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4857068/80003574-84d00000-84c1-11ea-8ae2-c20151f4f22c.png)


But there seems to be no way to include `0` without having a seemingly wrong assignment of tickmarks.

## Expected Behavior

The tick marks of the bars should correspond to the values associated to the bars.

## Versions
I installed the current master of this repo
```python
>>> import plotnine as pn
>>> pn.__version__
'0.6.0+48.g8125f00'
```
and run it under Python 3.7.3 in a x86_64-conda environment on Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS.

items.title: Setting name of scale_color_continuous legend
items.body:
Greetings,

I was puzzled by this on a recent plot. Here's a reproducible example:

```
import pandas as pd
import random
from plotnine import *

random.seed(1)

df = pd.DataFrame({'x': [random.randrange(100) for _ in range(100)],
                   'y': [random.randrange(100) for _ in range(100)],
                   'c': [random.randrange(5) for _ in range(100)]})
p = ggplot(df, aes(x='x', y='y', color='c')) + geom_point()
p
```

By default, we get a `viridis` continous color scale:
![grab_2020-03-14_132014](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/379357/76688001-e2397d00-65f6-11ea-9a26-e72dde5cb0db.png)


I wanted to change the name, so I added this line:
```
p = ggplot(df, aes(x='x', y='y', color='c')) + geom_point()
p = p + scale_color_continuous(name='foo')
p
```

I got this error instead:
```
ValueError: 'foo' is not a valid value for name; supported values are [list of color palette names]
```

For some silly reason I thought to try the european R ggplot spelling instead, which works but changes the color scale...
```
p = ggplot(df, aes(x='x', y='y', color='c')) + geom_point()
p = p + scale_colour_continuous(name='foo')
p
```
![grab_2020-03-14_132222](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/379357/76688004-e82f5e00-65f6-11ea-84f1-cc74479f1e66.png)

How can I have both a `viridis` palette and a custom scale name? I'm sure this is something trivial I'm overlooking, but I haven't figured it out! Many thanks.

items.title: SettingWithCopyWarnings generated by internal plotnine code
items.body:
For instance in `plotnine/positions/position.py`, within `position.transform_position()`, 
Pandas would prefer something along the lines of `data.loc[:,xs] = data[xs].apply(trans_x)`

```
        if trans_x:
            xs = [name for name in data.columns if name in X]
            data[xs] = data[xs].apply(trans_x)

        if trans_y:
            ys = [name for name in data.columns if name in Y]
            data[ys] = data[ys].apply(trans_y)
```

### The warning looks like this:
```
.../python3.8/site-packages/pandas/core/frame.py:2963: SettingWithCopyWarning: 
A value is trying to be set on a copy of a slice from a DataFrame.
Try using .loc[row_indexer,col_indexer] = value instead
```

items.title: `geom_map` uses incorrect color/fill indexing, is incompatible with faceting
items.body:
### Overview

Hey there!

When attempting to add `facet_wrap` to a plot using `geom_map`, I ran into this exception:

   IndexError: positional indexers are out-of-bounds

In the Traceback, it is this section of `geom_map.py` that's the culprit:

https://github.com/has2k1/plotnine/blob/246252c6b2e84a8e7dc83ee8661972496d22a1ab/plotnine/geoms/geom_map.py#L98-L105

After a bit of messing around, I discovered two bugs in the code.

### Bug 1

`cidx` and `fidx` are indices produced through subsetting and therefore have in-index values, but the lines where `color` and `fill` columns are set use `iloc`, which uses a positional indices. This works for non-faceted plots (and the first facet) because the index is created as an Int64Index, where positional index is the same as the associated index value, but not for other facets, where they do not match.

One potential fix is to use `.loc` instead of `.iloc` and ignore the `_loc` function:

        cidx = data.index[data['color'].isnull()]
        fidx = data.index[data['fill'].isnull()]
        data.loc[cidx, 'color'] = 'none'
        data.loc[fidx, 'fill'] = 'none'

### Bug 2

I thought this would fix everything, but the same type of issue occurs just after when figuring out the geometry type.

Specifically, `data.geometry.loc[0].geom_type` looks up the index value of 0, rather than the positional value, and facets other than the first one won't have this value. The easiest fix is to use `iloc`: `data.geometry.iloc[0].geom_type`.

### Summary

Replacing the current lines 98-105 with this code should fix the issue. Let me know if it's better for me to create a pull request:

        _loc = data.columns.get_loc
        cidx = data.index[data['color'].isnull()]
        fidx = data.index[data['fill'].isnull()]
        data.loc[cidx, 'color'] = 'none'
        data.loc[fidx, 'fill'] = 'none'
        data['fill'] = to_rgba(data['fill'], data['alpha'])

        geom_type = data.geometry.iloc[0].geom_type

`_loc` is also no longer used in this code and could be removed.

items.title: geom_text va="baseline" option missing in documentation
items.body:
The documentation for the va parameter in plotnine.geoms.geom_text lists the available options as "top", "center", or "bottom." 

https://plotnine.readthedocs.io/en/stable/generated/plotnine.geoms.geom_text.html

However, I was happy to discover that "baseline", listed in the va options for plotnine.themes.element_text, is also a valid option, aligning the baseline of the font with the y value of the point on the plot, and allowing descenders to fall below this point.

https://plotnine.readthedocs.io/en/stable/generated/plotnine.themes.element_text.html

items.title: Add `interaction` function
items.body:
[ggplot in R](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18598953/geom-line-connects-points-mapped-to-different-groups) has a function called `interaction` that makes it easy to `group` plots on the combination of two columns without having to create a new column. For example, the following code snippet I just wrote:

```python
df = ...
df['group'] = df.domain_levels.astype('str') + '-' + df.rcode_name.astype('str')
p = ggplot(tmp, aes(x='ts_by_hour',
                    y='count',
                    group='group',
                    color='domain_levels',
                    shape='rcode_name'))
```

could instead be written

```python
df = ...
p = ggplot(tmp, aes(x='ts_by_hour',
                    y='count',
                    group=interaction('domain_levels', 'rcode_name'),
                    color='domain_levels',
                    shape='rcode_name'))
```

Apologies if this is included under another name! I only searched for `interaction` in the repo. It's a pretty minor improvement, but I'm hoping that means it's also simple to do :).

Thanks for `plotnine`!

items.title: Use clip_on to show full geom on axis?
items.body:
Hassan,

Thanks for the amazing library.  One question: I am trying to show full points that are on an axis, but they are being truncated. I don't want to use expand, I want to keep the axes where they are.  From [what I have read](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9912206/how-do-i-let-my-matplotlib-plot-go-beyond-the-axes), I believe I need to somehow pass clip_on = False to the underlying matplotlib call. I've tried it a couple of ways in this example (both simultaneously), but it doesn't seem to work. How can I show the full circle for all 4 points in this toy example, which I've executed in Jupyter Lab?

Thanks,
Aaron


```from plotnine import *
import plotnine
import matplotlib
import pandas as pd

print(f"plotnine version: {plotnine.__version__}, matplotlib version {matplotlib.__version__}")
thechart = (
    ggplot(mapping=aes(clip_on=False))
    + geom_point(data=pd.DataFrame([[0,0],[0.5,0],[1,1],[2,2]],columns= ['x','y']),
                mapping=aes(x='x',y='y',clip_on=False),
                size=4)
    + scale_y_continuous(expand=[0, 0])
    + scale_x_continuous(expand=[0, 0])
)
display(thechart)
```

```R
  coord_flip() + 
  theme(axis.text.y=element_text(color=colors))
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10958332/68872064-b7e5ba80-06fd-11ea-8ce5-7b950b3ce4ed.png)

#### In `plotnine`:

```python
colors = ['blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green'] * 8

(ggplot(mtcars) 
  + aes('name', 'wt')  
  + geom_col()  
  + coord_flip()  
  + theme(axis_text_y=element_text(color=colors)))
```
```
 ValueError: Invalid RGBA argument: ('blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green', 'blue', 'red', 'orange', 'green') 
```
It looks like you can only set a single color for all the ticks but I have no clue on how to individually set the color for each of the labels.

With `matplotlib` figure objects you can expose and modify the tick labels by using `plt.gca().get_xticklabels()`. Is there any way to access to this level in a `plotnine` figure?

items.title: What's the idiomatic way to do line/ribbon geom for y/ymin/ymax stats?
items.body:
Sorry for posting a question rather than a bug, but this has bothered me for a long time. I love how simple it is to use `stat_summary` with `geom=pointrange`, but what I really want is to plot the central tendency with a `geom_line` and the `[ymin,ymax]` with a  `geom_ribbon`, which is much easier on the eyes than the `pointrange` geom. What's the proper way to achieve this?

If I have

```python
(ggplot(df, aes(x="x", y="y"))
 + stat_summary(geom="pointrange")
)
```

then I can instead do

```python
(ggplot(df, aes(x="x", y="y"))
 + stat_summary(geom="geom_ribbon", fill="#999999")
 + stat_summary(geom="geom_line", color="#333333")
)
```

but I worry this recomputes the statistics. The documentation for `stat_summary` says

> Calculated aesthetics are accessed using the _calc_ function. e.g. `stat(ymin)`.

This suggests I can add one instance of `stat_summary` to my plot and then add geoms that use the results, e.g. something like:

```python
(ggplot(df, aes(x="x", y="y"))
 + stat_summary(geom="ribbon", fill="#999999")
 + geom_line(aes(y="stat(y)"), color="#333333")
)
```

Unfortunately I haven't found any variation of this incantation that works. Maybe I shouldn't be using `stat(ymin)` literally, or maybe the word `calc` should be involved somehow? Am I thinking about this all wrong?

items.title: nudge_x and nudge_y breaking bar plot with position='fill'
items.body: I'm using plotnine in a Python notebook on the Azure Databricks platform (Spark 2.4). I have a dataset with -- for these purposes -- three related categorical variables. I am trying to visually represent the relative frequency of one of them (`vs`) given a second variable with three groups (`cyl`) and stratified by the last variable with two groups (`am`). I prefer to use the relative frequency because the absolute frequency (counts) of `vs` are scaled differently across the `cyl` groups. This is my current code (separately, I am working out the best way to get the % label by group, since currently it is calculating the proportion of `vs` across all `cyl` and not just within each `cyl` group, but I'm leaving it in to complete the example): ``` from plotnine.data import mtcars g = (ggplot(mtcars, aes('factor(cyl)', fill = 'factor(vs)')) + geom_bar(position = 'fill') + scale_y_continuous(labels=lambda l: ["%d%%" % (v * 100) for v in l]) + facet_wrap('am') + geom_text((aes(label = 'stat(count)')), stat = 'count', size=8, position = 'fill', nudge_x=-0.3, nudge_y=-0.1, va = 'top') + geom_text((aes(label = 'stat(prop)*100', group = 'vs')), # This isn't currently giving me the right % share stat = 'count', format_string = '({:.1f}%)', size=8, position = 'fill', nudge_x=0.3, nudge_y=-0.1, va = 'top') ) ``` The problem is that the inclusion of either `nudge_x` or `nudge_y` completely does away with the placement from `position = 'fill'`. I haven't come across any documentation where that would be intentional. If I ignore them for now: ``` from plotnine.data import mtcars g = (ggplot(mtcars, aes('factor(cyl)', fill = 'factor(vs)')) + geom_bar(position = 'fill') + scale_y_continuous(labels=lambda l: ["%d%%" % (v * 100) for v in l]) + facet_wrap('am') + geom_text((aes(label = 'stat(count)')), stat = 'count', size=8, position = 'fill', ## nudge_x=-0.3, ## nudge_y=-0.1, va = 'top') + geom_text((aes(label = 'stat(prop)*100', group = 'vs')), # This isn't currently giving me the right % share stat = 'count', format_string = '({:.1f}%)', size=8, position = 'fill', ## nudge_x=0.3, ## nudge_y=-0.1, va = 'top') ) ``` I get a plot like this: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16313397/67345813-1d74cb80-f4f1-11e9-9ab4-b577c44a5c76.png) It's close to what I want, but I'd like to replicate the labeling from the "show counts and percentages for bar plots" plotnine tutorial and obviously I need to get better separation between the labels. The code that includes `nudge_x` and `nudge_y`, however, produces this: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16313397/67345895-83615300-f4f1-11e9-8d16-4d4ee0d0ba92.png) Note how the y-axis has been rescaled and the value labels no longer retain the positions that actually correspond to the bars. I tried just using `nudge_x`, just in case that could be done without affecting the scaling of the y-axis, but the result was the same.

items.title: automatic ticks distribute unexpectedly in log scale
items.body:
Using `scale_y_log10` for my data `df` produces unhelpful ticks as in this example:
```
pl = (pn.ggplot(pn.aes('iteration', 'loss', color='lable'), df)
      + pn.geom_line(alpha=.6) + pn.scale_y_log10())
pl.draw();
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4857068/66646054-5aa1a980-ec25-11e9-8f3d-28ed1c8d77e4.png)

Admittedly, the range of `loss` is rather large and goes up to `1e+171`. Setting the ticks manually works better but not as satisfying as the automatic placement usually works and the minor ticks also seem off:
```
def breaks(limits):
    return np.geomspace(limits[0], limits[1], 10)
pl = (pn.ggplot(pn.aes('iteration', 'loss', color='lable'), df)
      + pn.geom_line(alpha=.6) + pn.scale_y_log10(breaks=breaks))
pl.draw();
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4857068/66646045-51184180-ec25-11e9-9289-e54dcdb05d68.png)

I used plotine from the current master branch 19f3172a77996860cf409000e9f687a666e39b1f and `df.loss.min() == 722399634.4616433`, `df.loss.max() == 4.995598277152082e+170`.

items.title: geom_line fails for groups with non-constant paths
items.body:
plotnine gives an error when trying to draw `geom_line` with non-constant path parameters, but for which lines with less than 2 data points were dropped.

I believe this is because the code below resets the index before removing single point lines https://github.com/has2k1/plotnine/blob/5a6abca57a1f8c6d091ef2648bfe2417350e587f/plotnine/geoms/geom_path.py#L87-L92

This then results in `iloc` indexing out of bounds
https://github.com/has2k1/plotnine/blob/5a6abca57a1f8c6d091ef2648bfe2417350e587f/plotnine/geoms/geom_path.py#L353-L356

Example:
```
from plotnine import *
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame({"A" : [1,1,1,1,1], 
              "B" : [0,0,1,2,2], 
              "C" : [1,1,1,1,1],
              "D" : [1,2,3,4,5]})
ggplot(df) + geom_line(aes(x="A", y="C", group="B", color="D"))
```
Error:
```
IndexError: index 4 is out of bounds for size 4
```

This is with version 0.6.0

items.title: geom_violin fails when the same values is often in the data
items.body:
plotnine gives unclear error and shows no violin plot, when a values appears to often in the to be plotted variable.

See the following example code:
```
import plotnine as p9
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

x = pd.DataFrame(data = np.array([np.ones(10), np.repeat(['A', 'B'], 5)]).T, columns=['ones', 'cat'])

p9.ggplot(x, p9.aes('factor(cat)', 'ones')) + p9.geom_violin()
```
Executing this example gives the following error:
`plotnine.exceptions.PlotnineError: 'Width not defined. Set with `position_dodge(width = ?)`'`

Running the same example in R ggplot2 produces a plot:
```
library(ggplot2)
library(data.table)

 x = data.table(ones = rep(1, 10), cat = rep(c('A', 'B')))
ggplot(x, aes(cat, ones)) + geom_violin()
```

The same happens, when there is only a small fraction of other values in the data.

Thanks!

items.title: facet_wrap scales argument produces unexpected behaviour paired with coord_flip
items.body:
In many occasions I find myself using `geom_bar` to plot counts of categorical variables. To properly display the names of the categorical variable values' it is usually useful to make the bar's orientation horizontal. `geom_bar` will only compute the count groupying by the `x` aesthetic so the only way to force bars to be horizontal is to use `coord_flip`.  This works fine, for instance, with a minimal example:

```{python3}
from plotnine.data import msleep
(p9.ggplot(msleep)
+ p9.aes('order')
+ p9.geom_bar()
+ p9.coord_flip()
)
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10958332/60344648-4956c900-99b7-11e9-94dc-ee4ad04e4054.png)

However, if now we are interested in facetting by any other variable and we want to tweak the scales:
+ If we choose `free_x`, none of the axes becomes free:

```
(p9.ggplot(msleep)
+ p9.aes('order')
+ p9.geom_bar()
+ p9.coord_flip()
+ p9.facet_wrap('bodywt > 50', scales='free_x')
)
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10958332/60344853-cb46f200-99b7-11e9-9629-174662120b97.png)

+ If we choose `free_y`, BOTH axes become free:
```
(p9.ggplot(msleep)
+ p9.aes('order')
+ p9.geom_bar()
+ p9.coord_flip()
+ p9.facet_wrap('bodywt > 50', scales='free_y')
)
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10958332/60344874-def25880-99b7-11e9-89b5-89bf9ecd57d5.png)

Choosing `free` works as expected (and exactly equal to `free_y` in this case). 

Any idea or workaround on how to fix this?

items.title: geom_boxplot() doesn't allow disabling out outliers
items.body:
In r, you can pass in `outlier.shape = NA` to [disable outliers from being plotted](https://github.com/tidyverse/ggplot2/issues/2505). Can this functionality be added to plotnine?

Using version 0.5.1
